title: 111_hr1956
content: The Act is titled the "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" and allows for the offset of state judicial debts against income tax refunds. The "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow for the collection of past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debts through income tax refund offsets. The "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" allows the Secretary to reduce overpayments to individuals by the amount of past-due State judicial debts owed, paying the reduced amount to the State judicial branch or agency. The Secretary can reduce overpayments to individuals by the amount of State judicial debts owed, pay the reduced amount to the State judicial branch or agency, and notify the individual of the reduction. The Secretary can reduce overpayments by the amount of State judicial debts owed, pay the reduced amount to the State agency, and notify the individual of the reduction. If an offset is made on a joint return, the notice must include the names, taxpayer identification numbers, and addresses of each filer. The overpayment is reduced to satisfy a past-due State judicial debt. If an offset is made on a joint return, the notice must include filers' names, taxpayer identification numbers, and addresses. The overpayment is reduced to satisfy past-due State judicial debt, with notice including filers' names, identification numbers, and addresses. The overpayment can be reduced to pay off past-due State judicial debt, as well as other types of debts such as internal revenue tax, past-due support, debts to Federal agencies, and State income tax obligations. The overpayment can be used to pay off past-due State income tax obligations, covered unemployment compensation debt, and debts owed to Federal agencies before being credited towards future Federal internal revenue tax liability. The overpayment can be used to pay off past-due State income tax obligations, covered unemployment compensation debt, and debts owed to Federal agencies before being credited towards future Federal internal revenue tax liability. If multiple debts are owed to State agencies or the State judicial branch, any overpayment by the person will be applied against those debts. If the Secretary receives notice of multiple debts owed to State agencies or the State judicial branch, any overpayment by the person will be applied against those debts in the order they accrued. Rules similar to subsection (e)(4) apply to debts under this subsection. For past-due, legally enforceable state judicial debt, specific rules apply. For past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debts, rules similar to subsection (e)(4) apply, and debts are prioritized based on the order they accrued. The term `past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debt' refers to a debt resulting from a court judgment in criminal or traffic cases, with an assessed and past-due amount. State judicial debt includes court costs, fees, fines, assessments, and other monies from court judgments or sentences. The Secretary will issue regulations for State judicial branches and agencies to submit notices of past-due debts, including court costs, fees, fines, assessments, and restitution to crime victims. The Secretary will issue regulations for State judicial branches and agencies to submit notices of past-due debts, including court costs, fees, fines, assessments, and restitution to crime victims, as well as prescribing the time and manner for submission and necessary information requirements. The regulations will specify the types of State judicial monies and the minimum debt amount eligible for reduction. State judicial branches and agencies may be required to pay a fee to reimburse the Secretary for the cost of the reduction procedure. Fees paid will be used to reimburse appropriations that covered the cost of the procedure. Amendments are made to sections 6402(a) and 6402(d) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to include subsection (g) for reduction of overpayments related to State judicial debts.
